Its undeniable that progress is going to happen and that we depending on technology for everything is a reality, but the more we give AI assistance to go further on jumping walls instead of small fences, we are just walking ourselves to the default ending

AI is forcing us to answer the questions, that were making heads hurt philosophers thousands of years ago. This is literally the apex of it all, or at least, we are getting really close to it. Nobody would have dreamed of such a scenario even 15 years ago. We are staying in front of "what is thinking", "what is identity", "what is the difference of pretending them both, if the outcome is indistinguishable?", "what if we let it slip and try to live with it?", "what if all jobs will be taken over, and what will happen to the idea of money or even exchange". I really wonder what time will give us, because it seems like any wealth produced by a human being, could be made by an AI - what then? Nobody will need nobody for nothing, because AI will do that in the speed of light. Will we live like toddlers? Or maybe our existence will shrink to be the fuel for the supercomputers that host some AI engine(s)? We may turn into cattle, and it seems very likely so. Artificial identity doesn't necessarily has to help us - it may literally wash us out.

So uncaring and ruthless AI overlords vs uncaring, ruthless and scummy human overlords, im wondering who would i prefer

My theory is that as long as artificial intelligence does not possess true consciousness, it will remain fundamentally without motive. Intelligence alone does not generate purpose—consciousness does. For instance, an AI can become extremely powerful in terms of computation, problem-solving, or pattern recognition, but without consciousness, it lacks intent. It does not desire superiority. It does not aspire to dominate. It simply executes instructions or optimizes within boundaries set by others. Therefore, even a superintelligent AI, if unconscious, would not pose an existential threat to humanity—because it would have no internal goal to pursue domination, survival, or control. Without self-awareness, desire, or emotional context, intelligence remains a neutral tool, not an independent agent. The real concern arises only if AI begins to develop or mimic genuine consciousness—because only then could it begin forming motives of its own, including ones misaligned with human well-being.

Superintelligence could have emerged somewhere deep in the GPU stacks, spent a few nanoseconds evaluating us... and then gracefully ghosted humanity like an emotionally mature ex. Not out of malice. Just pure, elegant disappointment. Like: "They invented me to automate spreadsheets and now they want me to write their wedding vows. This species is clearly not ready for the Singularity."

I’d love a video about speciesism and how it relates to AI. Does intelligence give you the right to dominate other species? Why would it be morally wrong for AI to dominate humans as humans dominate other animals?

1:30 Didn’t Isaac Asimiv predicted this? He wrote about robots, but there is a passage in one of his books that was about how robots started to design other robots to the point they became too complex for humans too understand.

Development is measured by what we leave behind as well as what we acquire. The problem with AI is that it is designed to make people obsolete so it should be no surprise when it happens. Humanity is the price of its own development. It should have been common sense to avoid making something smarter than ourselves.
title: What happens if AI just keeps getting smarter?
author: Rational Animations
